headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Express Scripts Fourth Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. And I would now like to turn the conference over
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Express Scripts Fourth Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. And I would now like to turn the conference over to our host, Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. David Myers. Please go ahead.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us this morning. With me today is George Paz, Chairman and CEO; and Jeff Hall, CFO. Before we begin, I need to read the following Safe Harbor statement. Statements or comments made on this cal
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us this morning. With me today is George Paz, Chairman and CEO; and Jeff Hall, CFO. 
Before we begin, I need to read the following Safe Harbor statement. Statements or comments made on this call today may be forward-looking and may include, but are not necessarily limited to, financial projections or other statements on the company's plans, objectives, expectations or intentions. These matters involve certain risks and uncertainties. The company's actual results may differ significantly from those projected or suggested in any forward-looking statement due to variety of factors, which are discussed in detail in our filings with the SEC.
For clarity purposes, all numbers we'll talk about today will be on an adjusted basis. Please refer to the tables in our press release for a reconciliation of GAAP to the adjusted numbers we will be discussing. The reconciliation of EBITDA to net income can also be found in our earnings release, which is posted on our website.
At this point, I'll turn the call over to Jeff, who'll discuss our fourth quarter results.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Last night, we reported fourth quarter EPS of $0.82, up 15% from the prior year. EPS for the year was $2.97, up 19%. Cash flow from operations was $532 million for the quarter and $2.2 billion for the year.Since our last call, we continue
componenttext:
Thanks, David. Last night, we reported fourth quarter EPS of $0.82, up 15% from the prior year. EPS for the year was $2.97, up 19%. Cash flow from operations was $532 million for the quarter and $2.2 billion for the year.
Since our last call, we continue to make progress towards completing the Medco acquisition, including securing the remainder of the financing, obtaining shareholder approval and certifying our substantial compliance with the FTC second request.
As a result of this progress, we maintained high levels of project spending to free up capacity for integration activities in 2012 and delayed cost savings opportunity, keeping staffing at higher levels to support integration planning.
SG&A expense costs were up $17 million year-over-year, reflecting the increased spending in an accrual for tax items, partially offset by lower management compensation.
Despite this increased spending, gross profit margin was 7.4%, in line with last year's fourth quarter. EBITDA was up 8% over last year. EBITDA per adjusted Rx rose to $3.66, up 6%; and EPS grew 19% for the year.
Although EPS was strong, it was below our target due to lower claims volume driven by utilization and increased attrition as a result of poor economic environment. Increased spending on projects and higher staffing levels to prepare for integration and investing to support clients and members as they change retail pharmacies.
Because EPS was below target, management bonuses were 0 in 2011. During the quarter, we settled $725 million of the remaining $750 million accelerated share repurchase, resulting in a receipt of 2.1 million additional shares. These shares are excluded from our outstanding shares this quarter.
The ASRs have resulted in a retirement 33.4 million shares of this year. 
As we've been saying for the past several months, we plan to provide combined 2012 guidance after the closing of the transaction, when we have had a chance to review and consolidate our forecast for the year.
Our view of the transaction remains unchanged. We believe that the acquisition will be slightly accretive to adjusted EPS in the first full year after closing and moderately accretive once fully integrated. We expect to realize $1 billion in net synergies once fully integrated. And at this point, I'll turn the call over to George.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and thank you, Jeff. The actions we took in 2011 demonstrated our ability to advance healthcare to innovation, execute on our unwavering alignment with clients and position ourselves to address the national mandate for more afforda
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and thank you, Jeff. The actions we took in 2011 demonstrated our ability to advance healthcare to innovation, execute on our unwavering alignment with clients and position ourselves to address the national mandate for more affordable healthcare, higher quality healthcare to our merger with Medco.
We succeeded by helping our clients solve issues in an industry that's ever-changing and ever-challenging, which positions us well for 2012 and beyond. Our research in new solutions lab continues to deliver innovative products and solutions that addresses our clients' main points such as adherence, which leads to $300 billion in healthcare waste each year.
We launched screen Rx, a new product offering, were predictive modeling is employed to determine which numbers are likely to be non-adherent in the future and tailor and intervention to best suit each individual. We are setting a new standard in healthcare by fighting non-adherence before it begins. 
Another tool that continues to gain traction in the marketplace is special benefit services, and the innovative offering that addresses the skyrocketing cost of special specialty drugs across the pharmacy medical spectrum. We can forecast, guarantee and deliver measurable savings by proven tools for specialty drugs, regardless of where patients receive the medication.
Our innovative approach to the marketplace, ability to drive positive clinical behavior and unwavering commitment to alignment contribute to a strong selling season with 97% retention, 3 signature wins and positive script growth expected for 2012.
And as we expected that this momentum will continue into the current selling season, one reason for our confidence is successfully executing our retail strategy. With Planning and execution of significant client support, we execute the largest retail market share movement in the history of pharmacy. 
We accomplish this with very little disruption, while delivering savings to our clients and patients by eliminating a high cost provider from our network.
We continue to make progress towards closing the transition -- transaction with Medco. The combination of our complementary strengths will accelerate our clinical offerings, which will reduce healthcare costs and improve health outcomes.
By blending the combined clinical skill with the behavioral sciences, we will be able to accelerate efforts to promote greater efficiencies in the healthcare system and better protect American families from the rising cost of prescription medications.
Our shared vision is to increase therapy adherence, lower costs and drive the better health outcomes. At this point, we'll be happy to answer any questions.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from the line of Lisa Gill with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from the line of Lisa Gill with JPMorgan.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: My first question, George, would just be around your comments on Walgreens and the success around our strategy. Can maybe just update us, you said little disruption, but whether costs in the fourth quarter and do you have costs in the first quarter associ
componenttext: My first question, George, would just be around your comments on Walgreens and the success around our strategy. Can maybe just update us, you said little disruption, but whether costs in the fourth quarter and do you have costs in the first quarter associated with moving people away from Walgreens? And then secondly, what has been the feedback as you start to move into the next selling season around more narrow networks and around Walgreens in general? And then I guess, my last question would be, are you in current discussions with Walgreens? Or have you had discussions since your last earnings call with Walgreens around coming back together?

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll try to remember to hit all those points and hope you're -- well, Lisa, if I missed something, just remind me. Yes, as we ramped up our call centers associates, both in our from pharmacy helpdesk and our patient care advocates, significantly in
componenttext: Okay, I'll try to remember to hit all those points and hope you're -- well, Lisa, if I missed something, just remind me. Yes, as we ramped up our call centers associates, both in our from pharmacy helpdesk and our patient care advocates, significantly in the fourth quarter and the first quarter. Keep in mind, we had a huge wins in our Medicare clients that brought a lot of new lives into the fourth quarter. That, coupled with all the Medicare changes that normally take place, plus all the benefit design changes that occur on 11. And then quite frankly, roughly 20% of our book had been in Walgreens stores, and almost all of that was scheduled to move, and so we wanted to make sure that this 11 went flawlessly. We decided we would over expand in order to make sure that the client experience and the member experience was the best that we could have. And I think we are rather successful that and quite frankly, we did over staff. But again, I think it was the right answer. The clients, although very incredibly supportive. We have an obligation to them to make sure this went up without a hitch. And we needed to make sure that every member can call than that was looking for a convenient outlet or a way to process prescriptions whether it was a movement to mail or to another retailer that we would make sure we could handle that and give them top-class service. And our operations people executed in an exemplary manner. I would tell you that there was -- the movement has been very but good for us. It really does endorse the fact that specially narrower networks and in fact do work. At the end of the day, taking out large retailer like this, it effects to a narrow network. We don't have -- and 98.5%, 98.4%, somewhere in that range of our book is now in the narrow network, so we feel very good about it. Our clients are very supportive. I think what really speaks to it is the fact that this did go off. Nobody's -- our phones aren't ringing. People aren't -- our clients are not upset, so this has been, truly has been a good move for us and in our cost for our clients get better year-over-year. So we're excited about it not to the extent that Walgreens wants to come back, gnats to have a relationship, wants to help drive down the cost of healthcare, it can be -- I appreciate the fact that they are trying to do some very good things with respect to clinical offerings and other avenues to try to impact the overall healthcare spectrum. But quite frankly, that hasn't been proven to reduce costs. And many of the things that they're offering in the pharmacy are being offered by many others out there. So I don't see them as differentiated. And it just came with a good conscience, pay them a significant premium for something that everyone else is doing and doing this as well. So we are quite content where we sit today, and to the extent that they want to get the relationship and to be in line with the rest of healthcare costs and we're willing to entertain those conversations.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And George, I know it's early on in the selling season. Some of the Medicare pieces of the business are in renewal right now. Are they interested in talking about narrow networks? I mean, obviously, you've been successful in this. We've heard nice things
componenttext: And George, I know it's early on in the selling season. Some of the Medicare pieces of the business are in renewal right now. Are they interested in talking about narrow networks? I mean, obviously, you've been successful in this. We've heard nice things in the market as far as perceptiveness to moving to an narrow network. Just wondering what you see in the early days?

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think part of it is maybe a little bit selection as well, right, because we do have an offering with Walgreens. So people that are coming into we probably have eliminated some clients from an offering. I mean, something really gnats Walgreens, then call
componenttext: I think part of it is maybe a little bit selection as well, right, because we do have an offering with Walgreens. So people that are coming into we probably have eliminated some clients from an offering. I mean, something really gnats Walgreens, then call us up. But thousands and thousands of clients and millions and millions of Americans out there so there's markets pretty big enough. And the book we have certainly isn't overly cousins our isn't concerned. And I think the fact that we just picked up catalysts, I refer to that, picked up the client from catalysts in Maryland because of that publicly been put out there, speaks to the fact that people are willing to make those decisions if it saves money. This is a tough economy. And if you see your costs going up and somebody's giving been option, that can reduce your cost further without compromising healthcare outcomes or still improving health outcomes, why not take advantage of it? And I think that's what we offer and that's the same thing for even narrowing the weather network further is it does provide an opportunity to save money. And we may -- if you talk about scripts as being irrelevant, well, if you got 1 million script, that's $1 million a year. I would do some things for $1 million a year. I don't know by you, but that's a lot of money to me, and especially if I haven't done anything to compromise the outcomes. If everything is status quo, people still get thing pills, people are still getting their drugs, people are still have convenient access to pharmacists, what really the change? All we've done is put $1 million into our shareholders pockets that seems like a pretty smart thing to me. I don't laugh at $0.10 and $0.15 a script and especially when you start talking $1 script. That's real money.

Is that the right characterization?

componenttext: Well, I don't want to negotiate with Walgreens over the telephone with my investors. What I would say is that we are always open to the conversation and in negotiation, but it's got to being in the area best interest of our shareholders and patients.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: George and Jeff, just a couple of quick ones. Just elaborate a little bit on the selling season. It seems to us, given over half your business is long-term relationships, which we're continuing, your position for bid for the '13 selling season is pretty m
componenttext: George and Jeff, just a couple of quick ones. Just elaborate a little bit on the selling season. It seems to us, given over half your business is long-term relationships, which we're continuing, your position for bid for the '13 selling season is pretty modest in that sort of $5 billion to $6 billion range. You don't want to be specific, but is that the right ballpark, first of all? And then, along with that, with some discussion about the potential change of control, provision with Medco seems to be somewhat in dispute, so I was curious if you can comment on that with the successful completion of Medco?

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't want to really get into a lot of details about Medco. We haven't closed yet. What we do due diligence. We put a team together, we look at -- we can only see certain things because we are under specific rules set out by the FTC and others tha
componenttext: Well, I don't want to really get into a lot of details about Medco. We haven't closed yet. What we do due diligence. We put a team together, we look at -- we can only see certain things because we are under specific rules set out by the FTC and others that limit what we can actually see. So we've been diligent. We've looked at the company. We've got a history of doing acquisitions and making it work. And so I think we are pretty careful as to what we're going to get into. I feel good about -- I feel very good about this opportunity. I think it's the right thing for us. It brings together 2 very strong clinical companies that putting together can create even better clinical outcomes, and those things are going to speak tons for our clients and their ability to drive better health outcomes for their employees and patients. And I'm excited about this, Larry. I think it's a great opportunity, and we wouldn't narrow into a deal and all of a sudden all the clients begun. I think they're pretty smart about that.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for the clarification. Second is a follow-up this just mentioned, hallmarks of years is budgets aren't made and exceeded then management feels that and obviously, that was triggered this past year. And now historically, usually that budget is
componenttext: Okay, thanks for the clarification. Second is a follow-up this just mentioned, hallmarks of years is budgets aren't made and exceeded then management feels that and obviously, that was triggered this past year. And now historically, usually that budget is set on some parameters the company's guidance following your give or take. So I'm just curious, give the we're in transition here, how are management and sentiment is going to be structured this year around the budget given you're not yet given guidance yet? Is that yet to be determined? Or is this something already set that we'll get more details on?

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. Let me answer that in a couple of ways. First of all, you're right. We feel ourselves to be very much accountable to our shareholders. And if we make statements that make projections and don't live up to them, we don't feel it's right to reward
componenttext: Well, yes. Let me answer that in a couple of ways. First of all, you're right. We feel ourselves to be very much accountable to our shareholders. And if we make statements that make projections and don't live up to them, we don't feel it's right to reward ourselves is management and have our shareholders missed out. So yes, we take our bonuses down accordingly when we miss, and this was a big issue for me personally. I thought the economy was turning in the first- fourth quarter of last year. Things were going to improve. I didn't think that we could see 3 or 4 years in a row of 0 utilization increases. I thought that I saw the climate trend starting to pick back but did not occur. So between utilization and member attrition inside of our current book of business because of the missed earnings, once we got into that situation, we have a tremendous opportunity such as Medco in front of us. We decided the right answer was to accelerate spending and get ahead of a lot of the Medicare and Health Care Reform projects that were staring us in the face. So we've significantly increased our IT budgets as I talked about a few minutes ago. We also got a lot of staff and make sure that we are ready for 11, we're prepared for the huge migration of members away from Walgreens. And so we're very well positioned for that, and I think it was the right thing to do. And likewise, we didn't take bonuses. As far as 2012 is concerned, for me, 2012 we're spending a lot of money trying to get ready for Medco. There's a lot of hidden money, if you will, that you don't see because we have consultants and we have our teams are working on projects. Normally, what we'd be doing, we'd be looking other opportunities but instead, people are focused on meetings around integration planning. So things are a little bit on the back burner. We also know the importance of client. So what we have a group of people that are focused on integration, we have to really double down on client service because we have to make sure our clients understand that this is going to be status quo for them to this integration, and that they will not miss a beat in service, while we integrate Medco into our books. So takes a lot of people in a lot of effort to get all those things done. On that note, we've put together a sketchy preliminary budget for 2012, which we have internally. That numbers what we will base our bonuses on unlikely event we didn't close Medco. We would release those numbers out to you if that event were to occur, but I don't see that as happening. Instead, as soon as we close and we get our numbers together, we will come forward with a combined budget. To me, coming out with the '12 numbers is fairly irrelevant because it's too much dependent upon money we're spending with -- without a return, without the Medco deal. So it's just all that relevant. It becomes relevant, obviously, if the deal doesn't close. So we, at that time, we would disclose it.

Just wondering serve the baked in there what you think about the underlying market and your expectations for an improvement or deterioration you think about the year?

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: We constantly hear about employment trends and that it's going the right direction and the jobs are in fact picking up but we're not seeing a whole lot of that, unfortunately. I think what we're seeing is that people are employing people, but they're doin
componenttext: We constantly hear about employment trends and that it's going the right direction and the jobs are in fact picking up but we're not seeing a whole lot of that, unfortunately. I think what we're seeing is that people are employing people, but they're doing it in a more on a temporary basis, consulting basis and not necessarily bringing people back into permanent positions the way we've seen our recession, what we've come out of a recession in the past. So employment pickup has not been overwhelmingly large in our book of businesses, and just haven't seen it. Likewise, utilization continues to be very concerning. It's concerning to me as a citizen of the United States because if people aren't taking their medications, we know people are getting skinnier, and we know they're not getting healthier. And if utilization is going up as the baby boomers are getting into those later years, there's some fundamentally wrong here, and all that is going to relate into higher ER visits and higher doctor and hospital costs in the future, which is not a good thing for our country, but that's what we're headed. So we remain for 2012 in our planning. We're assuming that the -- that job growth won't come about, but it's not going to decline. It's going to stay relatively flat, and the utilization trends are going to stay below 1% or right close to 1% for this year, which is, again, very concerning, but we figured that's the prudent thing to do at this juncture.

componenttext: Yes, we are going out to the clients and it flows through to the client so were dealing with clients each and everyone. I don't think we've aggregated or made a public debt. But maybe as we get further into the year, we'll give those numbers out. As far as the -- the other question was around Walgreens -- oh, the staffing levels. Yes, we do over time is we were in clear January 31 and got through all that. So once we got beyond that date, then we start attrition and taking out the less productive employees and going on and give people some time off and what-have-you. We also want to make sure we're probably geared up for the whole Medco integration situation. As you probably know when you go through a merger, a lot of people get members in the leave and so some employment trends can get hurt. Just want to make sure we were purple the staffer that as well. So we're being cautious here as we progress through this year.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob. So that $20 million number is not a number that came from us. So it's hard for me to comment on it. We haven't been specific on what we said the increase costs are, what George said, I'll concur with it. Certainly, there's a lot of costs that on
componenttext: Yes, Bob. So that $20 million number is not a number that came from us. So it's hard for me to comment on it. We haven't been specific on what we said the increase costs are, what George said, I'll concur with it. Certainly, there's a lot of costs that on in the fourth quarter. That costs is continuing to the first quarter as we really gear up for integration, but we haven't been specific. As we think just in broader terms as said by George a little bit earlier, 2012 is going to be a year where there's going to be more people around and more spending around as we focus on integration. Really, the focus on 2012 was going to be driving integration, getting to the synergy and as a result, those are our top priorities, not tweaking every last penny out of EPS, so much more focused on integration synergy, making it all flawless to the clients and much less focused on earnings.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012

componenttext: Okay. And on a separate issue, you cited Medicaid in Canada volumes as reasons for some upside to the scriptures here and not really better adherence from the behavior of efforts that you have. I mean, when does that coil spring a potential really going to kind of uncork year?

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a great question. We are actually very focused on adherence and following it. We've got several -- we've been at this for a couple of years. We rolled out several pilots. And I think with those clients that we are working with an either pilot
componenttext: Well, that's a great question. We are actually very focused on adherence and following it. We've got several -- we've been at this for a couple of years. We rolled out several pilots. And I think with those clients that we are working with an either pilot format or actually rollouts and programs, we are seeing some improvements but it's not across the book of business yet. The real issue for us, Bob, although we are still investing heavily in consumerology and positioning ourselves, we are still -- we're looking forward to the day when we close the Medco transaction. And they've got a lot of great clinical programs as well. So we want to make sure that we don't get too far out so we can't incorporate their best practices as well. So although we're doing some infrastructure buildout to allow our systems and all our people to grab great access to information so we could monitor averaging things, we're also going a little bit slower going a lot of it's lower from a client rollout perspective so that we can make sure we have the right offering that when we hit the marketplace.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012

componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of Ross Muken with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's Mike in for us today. So you guys, have addressed obviously of the the what you've done so far with Medco and the limitations you have in terms of being able to get in some information perspective. But given the fact that your 3 to 4 months for the d
componenttext: It's Mike in for us today. So you guys, have addressed obviously of the the what you've done so far with Medco and the limitations you have in terms of being able to get in some information perspective. But given the fact that your 3 to 4 months for the down the line in terms of integration planning, can you give a little the compare contract in terms of what you're seeing from perspective for Medco versus what you did with an NextRx? And George, you mentioned strong track record of be successful integration. So I guess, how is this compared to that? What other challenges do you think that make this a little more complex than the NextRx innovation?

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, this is going to be quite a bit more complex than that. When we brought up NextRx, there was a single client we had to deal with, WellPoint. And WellPoint is a great partner. We'll gotten great things together and we cherish our relationship. But at
componenttext: Well, this is going to be quite a bit more complex than that. When we brought up NextRx, there was a single client we had to deal with, WellPoint. And WellPoint is a great partner. We'll gotten great things together and we cherish our relationship. But at the end of the day, we had a single point of contact. So we could work with their people in order to figure out our direction, we're where going and make sure that we are doing the things that benefit our company's. When we look out at Medco, here we're talking about thousands of clients. And we've got to make sure that when we do is meeting needs and positioning ourselves properly for our combined book of business going forward. So it's going to be a lot tougher. There's a lot more plan designs, a lot more specialization clients, many of them do things different than others. So we're going to have to really make sure that we have an offering that allows us to get to our synergies yet meet the needs of those clients and that's going to be our focus once we close.

componenttext: Well, as this part of the business is growing and is proven to be a very successful program, we continue to look at ways to help our Medicare business is made up of several different buckets. We offer PDP program for our clients that want to take advantage of our get the opportunities. So when the government cut back on the tax benefits attributable to self-insure the programs, PDP has became a tremendous opportunity as an offering to get a better tax opportunity out of the plants. And so we have a very good strong offering there. We continue to grow that. I think we've seen significant growth in that area. Our managed care clients themselves are outgrowing their own Medicare business and we are supplementing that and helping them. Historically, we have not had a direct to consumer business in our own. That something we didn't get into. As you referenced, Medco does have that business, and we will closely look at it and look at the opportunities there once we have an opportunity to emerge.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, let me answer that in a couple of ways. First of all, when we're out competing for business. We often find out we lost business because we were $0.10 a script out of the market, and people move on $0.10. And so I sit there and I struggle with what d
componenttext: Well, let me answer that in a couple of ways. First of all, when we're out competing for business. We often find out we lost business because we were $0.10 a script out of the market, and people move on $0.10. And so I sit there and I struggle with what does it really mean then when narrow network won't with it? If I'm going to move it disrupt my entire work of business and change formularies for $0.10, and I can save $0.50 to $2, depending on how narrow I want to make the network even more and there's a lot more and $0.10. So it's hard for me to get my arms around that issue. I think the concern, though, by many was if I'm going to save $1 by narrowing this network or $2 by narrowing the network, whatever the number is, is that enough because the was this feeling that the denying access to a given pharmacy may play haven't gone my HR department and what disruption this might be and how upset I am pleased going to be? Well, what we just figure out through this process was it was virtually none. That doesn't mean that somebody that wasn't tied to Walgreens is an individual that didn't have to run new pharmacists at Kroger or CBS or wherever then in that going and become friends with a new pharmacists and that is where it is. But it really did go up without a hitch. At the end of day, as I said earlier, next is LIPITOR is LIPITOR. Drugs are drugs and it shouldn't matter that much those I just believe that we should be able to make sure that would put the right person in front of the right costs and make sure that we serve our clients properly. Taking costs out of the healthcare system is of paramount importance to us and that's what were going to do. And I do think that the narrow network speak to that and serve that occasion. And depending on what happens with the economy. When the employee year is looking at laying off hundreds and hundreds of people HR director  and I come in with a proposal that saves a $1 million, how welcome is that going to be? Nobody. As a CEO, I don't particularly to lay off people. I'd don't think any of my peers like to lay off people. And we all have our demands and needs to meet our shareholders expectations, so there's a lot of pressure on the CEO. And if you can deliver them without disrupting your client base, I think that's critically important. So we are absolutely focused on that, and we believe that the community pharmacists severance a very important role in healthcare, that they do a tremendous amount. But we just don't see that 1 pharmacist does it -- does much better than another pharmacists at least, not by a change. So we're just not going to pay those premiums.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: From our perspective, we're working very diligently and focused on getting us through the FTC, making sure we meet their needs. The FTC and doing their job. They're trying to make sure that the American public is going to do better because of this acquisi
componenttext: From our perspective, we're working very diligently and focused on getting us through the FTC, making sure we meet their needs. The FTC and doing their job. They're trying to make sure that the American public is going to do better because of this acquisition. And we're right there with them. We believe that this acquisition speaks to what this country needs more than anything, which is a reduction in the cost of healthcare and whether to show them previous acquisitions, that's occurred and through this acquisition, it will continue to occur. At the end of the day, that's a lot of pushback from the retail pharmacists because they're worried about as us the costs for reimbursement. Well, that's our job. The job is that the cost of branded products go up at roughly 10% a year. If we're not in there and try to negotiate part of that 10% for our clients, then all that goes back to the pharmacies. That can't occur. People can get a 10% per unit increase each and every year. It's okay if you can move people from brands to generics from a higher cost struggle or lower cost drug and save that patient money to make more money but not just by spending still. And all of a sudden, in December 31, I feel one 1 prescription January 2, I feel the next one, all of a sudden, I make 10% more. That just doesn't make any sense. And would have to be insulated, that filtered that takes of the equation get sit back to our clients, and that's a very important role. That's the problem with what we have with Walgreens in the situation is that they wanted us to hold rates flat and hold them flat over a 3-year period, and that can't occur. That lines the pockets of Walgreens by 10% increase each and every year ever, are currently entire than facing not only 10% in brand rents, do not getting the benefits from the generics hold those that as well. And they wanted to get all the utilization increases. And that's just -- we just can't stand there and allow that to happen. So our job is to make sure our clients to maintain reductions in prices. If you look at our industry, year in, year out, as clients come out for renewal, their prices come down. That's what we do. As we go out and get we get better discounts for our clients and I think it's an important role. As far as what we might have to do or anything else, that's not a pertinent question at that time because we're in the process of trying to solve and make sure that the government is comfortable with this with what we're doing and we're going to get through that first and we have any -- if there's anything we needed to discuss later, we'll be happy to make sure you are all informed of that. But we feel good about where we stand and were going to love this conclusion.

headline: Express Scripts Inc., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Catalysts over has up to them, they've done great job of growing the company and really being a key player in our industry. It's a very formidable competitor. Mark does a great job out there this United a strong competitor with their size and
componenttext:
Absolutely. Catalysts over has up to them, they've done great job of growing the company and really being a key player in our industry. It's a very formidable competitor. Mark does a great job out there this United a strong competitor with their size and strength and they've got strong offerings. That's what makes this industry great. If we can fulfill and just do what we did yesterday, we've got to continue to innovate and create and come up with new opportunities to take costs out of the systems to be ahead of our competition. And I believe we do have a good job at it, that's why we've been able to grow. And we will commitment to our shareholders and our patients is to continue down that path.
Well, thank you everyone for joining us on our year-end conference call and earnings, and we look forward to keeping you posted as we progress towards our culmination of our closing with the transaction with Medco. Thank you very much.
